com.github.sahasatvik.cli

Class ArgHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.github.sahasatvik.cli.ArgHandler

  • public class ArgHandler
extends java.lang.Object
    This class parses command line arguments, and enables simple retrieval of options and arguments. Any class which needs to use this library must create an ArgHandler object, and pass to it an array of arguments, as well as a list of Option objects which can be accepted from the argument array.

    Options are separated from arguments : any String starting with '-' is a 'short' option, while those starting with '--' are long options. Short options can be grouped together : '-abc' is recognized as the group of options 'a', 'b' and 'c', and processed separately. Each short option is associated with it's long version, and thus, they can be used interchangeably. Options can also carry values attached to them, separated from the option by an '=' character. These values can also be retrieved separately for each option.

    Arguments are the Strings other than options, and are stored in a queue. They can be popped off the beginning, or pushed to the end. Using this library, the next Integer or Double value can also be retrieved and popped.

    In addition, errors such as the use of unknown options are detected, and suitable Exceptions are thrown.

    An example of ArgHandler's implementation is as follows : 

    

 class Example {
 	public static void main (String[] args) {

 		.
 		.
 		. 
      
	Option help = new Option("-h", "--help");		// Normal option without value. Note that 
							// no value can be queried from it using 
							// option.getValue() : attempting to 
							// do so throws a OptionException
	Option<Integer> min = new Option<Integer>("-m", "--min").canHaveValue(true)
							    .setValueType(Integer.class);
							// This Option may be assigned an Integer by 
							// ArgHandler while processing
	Option<Integer> max = new Option<Integer>("-M", "--max").canHaveValue(true)
							    .setValueType(Integer.class)
							    .setDefaultValue(10);
							// This Option will have a default value of 10, if no
							// value is set by ArgHandler
	Option<String> capsName = new Option<String>("-n", "--name").canHaveValue(true)
								.useParser((s) -> (s.toUpperCase()));
							// This option uses a lambda expression for 
							// Parser<T>, to parse the name into upperCase.
							// This means that while setting the value of the Option,
							// the raw String is parsed by the parser specified above,
							// which is a lambda expression here for brevity.
							
	try {
		ArgHandler a = new ArgHandler(args).useOptions(help, min, max, cpasName);
							// Create an ArgHandler and pass the Options to it
	} catch (ArgumentException e) {

	} catch ( . . .
		.
		.					// Continue catching all Exceptions
		.
	
	Boolean needsHelp = help.getState();		// The state of the Option can be retrieved 
							// by calling help.getState()
	Integer minVal = min.getValue();		// The value of min.getValue() can be stored 
							// directly in minVal, due to the use of generics
	Integer maxVal = max.getValue();		// If no value has been set, the default value
	String name = capsName.hetValue()		// specified will be returned
	try {
		String firstArg = a.next();		// Get the first argument
		Integer firstInteger = a.<Integer>next(Integer.class);
							// Get the first Integer	
		Parser<String> small = (s) -> (s.toLowerCase());	
		String smallName = a.<String>next(small);
							// Get the first argument which can be parsed
							// by 'small'
	} catch ( . . .
		.
		.
		.
 	}
 }
    Since:
    1.0
    Version:
    2.0, 04/09/2016
    Author:
    Satvik Saha

    • Constructor Detail

      • ArgHandler

        public ArgHandler(java.lang.String[] args)
        This is the only constructor of ArgHandler. Here, the array of arguments must be passed to ArgHandler. The arguments will be processed, and can be retrieved as if they were in a Queue.
        Parameters:
        args - the array of arguments to be processed
        Since:
        1.0

    • Method Detail

      • useOptions

        public ArgHandler useOptions(Option<?>... options)
                      throws OptionException
        This method must be called in order to initiate the processing of options in the array of arguments passed earlier. Option objects created earlier must be passed, which will be midified dynamically during processing. Only these options will be considered to be valid while processing. The presence of any option other than those passed here will trigger a OptionException.
        Parameters:
        options - the array of valid Options to be used
        Returns:
        this ArgHandler
        Throws:
        InvalidOptionException - thrown if an invalid Option is found
        OptionException - thrown if a value assigned to a Option cannot be parsed properly
        Since:
        2.0

      • getOption

        public Option<?> getOption(java.lang.String s)
                    throws InvalidOptionException
        This method returns the Option whose short or long form matches the String passed to it. Note that the Options collected by useOptions(Options[]) are used here.
        Parameters:
        s - the String to be compared with the Options
        Returns:
        the Option matching 's', if it exists
        Throws:
        InvalidOptionException - thrown if the Option matching 's' does not exist
        Since:
        2.0
        See Also:
        useOptions(Option[])

      • getOption

        public Option<?> getOption(char c)
                    throws InvalidOptionException
        This method returns the Option whose short form contains the charcter passed to it.
        Parameters:
        c - the character to be compared with the Options
        Returns:
        the Option matching 'c', if it exists
        Throws:
        InvalidOptionException - thrown if the Option matching 'c' does not exist
        Since:
        2.0
        See Also:
        getOption(String)

      • argCount

        public int argCount()
        Returns the number of arguments currently in the queue.
        Returns:
        number of arguments in the queue
        Since:
        1.2

      • hasMoreArgs

        public boolean hasMoreArgs()
        Returns true if the arguments queue still contains arguments.
        Returns:
        false, if all arguments have been popped out of the queue
        Since:
        1.2

      • next

        public java.lang.String next()
                      throws NoRemainingArgumentsException
        Returns the first argument in the queue, then pops it out.
        Returns:
        first argument in the queue
        Throws:
        NoRemainingArgumentsException - thrown if no arguments are left in the queue
        Since:
        1.2

      • next

        public <T> T next(java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
           throws NoRemainingArgumentsException,
                  NoArgumentOfRequiredTypeFoundException
        Returns the next argument of the class type 'clazz' passed to the method. If the first argument cannot be cast into the mentioned type, this method will loop through the remaining arguments until a suitable argument is found, or the end of the argument queue is reached.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the target type
        Parameters:
        clazz - the class of the target type
        Returns:
        the first argument which can be parsed a 'clazz'
        Throws:
        NoRemainingArgumentsException - thrown if no argument is found
        NoArgumentOfRequiredTypeFoundException - thrown if no parsable arguments are left
        Since:
        2.0
        See Also:
        Argument.getValue(Class)

      • next

        public <T> T next(Parser<T> parser)
           throws NoRemainingArgumentsException,
                  NoArgumentOfRequiredTypeFoundException
        Returns the next argument which can be parsed by the parser passed to the method. If the first argument cannot be parsed by the mentioned parser this method will loop through the remaining arguments until a suitable argument is found, or the end of the argument queue is reached.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the target type
        Parameters:
        parser - the parser to be used
        Returns:
        the first argument which can be parsed by 'parser'
        Throws:
        NoRemainingArgumentsException - thrown if no argument is found
        NoArgumentOfRequiredTypeFoundException - thrown if no parsable arguments are left
        Since:
        2.0
        See Also:
        Argument.getValue(Parser), Parser.parse(String)
